texts.shortText:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This species is fairly plump and oval, with a small head and pectoral fin longer than the head. Adult males have a slightly concave snout profile and bulge between the eyes. The mouth is small with 5 rows of incisors and no molars. Preoperculum (front part of operculum) without scales (distinguishing it from similar Blue hottentot). Colour bronze on body, head iridescent blue.
Up to 74 cm total length and a mass of up to 6 kg.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Maputo.

Found singly or in small groups on rocky reefs to a depth of about 25 m, usually in rough water and often near caves. Juveniles usually more inshore and among algae. Tend to be resident, sometimes remaining in the same area for years. Slow growing, reaching an age of at least 40 years. Sought after by anglers and spearfishers.
Feeds primarily on red and green algae and associated fauna.
Does not change sex and matures at a length of about 30 cm (age of 5 years). Spawns from January to June, eggs developing in the plankton.

Easily confused with the two other Pachymetopon species in the region. The Hottentot P. blochii (which is much the most common of the species) has a smaller eye and is fairly plain bronzy-brown. The Blue Hottentot P. aeneum is more elongate with a larger head and is grey-bronze streaked with blue and with a cobalt blue front to head. The anterior part of the operculum in the latter species is scaled.
